prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO1-0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The primary goal is to image the circumstellar environment of EP Aqr in the (1-0) rotational line of 12CO with a high spectral resolution, a high fidelity and a high sensitivity.
The high spectral resolution is required to constrain the kinematics of the wind which includes a slow component with a 1 km/s expansion velocity.
The high fidelity is required to constrain quantitatively the model which we will use to determine the density and the temperature throughout the shell.
The high sensitivity is needed to probe the environment at all geometrical scales. Based on previous Plateau de Bure observations we estimate the needed sensitivity to 15mJy in a beam of 0.5 arcsec.
From previous observations, the data obtained with ALMA should cover a field of 40 arcsec x 40 arcsec. The CO molecule is expected to be photodissociated at angular distances larger than 15 arcsec. The line is known to be centered at -34 km/s (LSR).
The second important goal is to image the central compact source. Here, we need a high point source sensitivity in the continuum, and a high spatial resolution. The goal is to locate it with respect to the center of symmetry of the outflow, and possibly to detect a companion.
Finally, we consider also the possibility to detect the C17O isotopologue.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The narrow component of the composite line profile is 2km/s wide (indicating an outflow velocity of 1 km/s), but narrower features down to ~ 0.5km/s are present in our PdBI maps. To properly resolve these spectrally and to have some margin for rebinning we ask for a velocity resolution of 0.1km/s (the same resolution obtained in our previous IRAM observations).

Our recent re-analysis of the IRAM data suggests kinematics structures at the smallest detectable scale. We consider the possible presence of a companion at a distance smaller than 1 arcsec from the central source. The largest angular scale is set by the CO photodissociation radius.

Previous PdBI observations indicate peak line fluxes of about 600mJy/beam at 2.5arcsec resolution for the faintest structures. In the most pessimistic case these structures would be smoothly distributed over the 25 synthesized beams of 0.5arcsec requested here, i.e. we should expect a flux of at least 24mJy/beam. The narrowest features seen in our previous observations show a velocity width of about 0.5km/s. For detecting faint structures, we can thus afford smoothing the spectra over up to five channels. To detect 24mJy/beam at 3 sigma in 0.5 km/s requires a sensitivity of 18mJy/beam in 0.1 km/s (which for safety we rounded to 15mJy/beam in the form in order to increase our ability to detect CO close to the photodissociation limit). In addition, for the faint structures, away from the center, we can consider binning them spatially.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The primary goal is to image the circumstellar environment of EP Aqr in the (2-1) rotational line of 12CO with a high spectral resolution, a high fidelity and a high sensitivity.
The high spectral resolution is required to constrain the kinematics of the wind which includes a slow component with a 1 km/s expansion velocity.
The high fidelity is required to constrain quantitatively the model which we will use to determine the density and the temperature throughout the shell.
The high sensitivity is needed to probe the environment at all geometrical scales. Based on previous Plateau de Bure observations we estimate the needed sensitivity to 15mJy in a beam of 0.25 arcsec.
From previous observations, the data obtained with ALMA should cover a field of 40 arcsec x 40 arcsec. The CO molecule is expected to be photodissociated at angular distances larger than 15 arcsec. The line is known to be centered at -34 km/s (LSR).
The second important goal is to image the central compact source. Here, we need a high point source sensitivity in the continuum, and a high spatial resolution. The goal is to locate it with respect to the center of symmetry of the outflow, and possibly to detect a companion.
Thirdly, observations in the 13CO line will be used to constrain the 13C/12C abundance ratio in the inner circumstellar shell.
Finally, we consider also the possibility to detect the C18O isotopologue, and the SiO (5-4) rotational line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The narrow component of the composite line profile is 2km/s wide (indicating an outflow velocity of 1km/s wide), but narrower features down to ~ 0.5km/s are present in our PdBI maps. To properly resolve these spectrally and to have some margin for rebinning we ask for a velocity resolution of 0.1km/s (the same resolution obtained in our previous IRAM observations).

Our recent re-analysis of the IRAM data suggests kinematics structures at the smallest detectable scale. We consider the possible presence of a companion at a distance smaller than 1 arcsec from the central source. To properly locate the companion and to clearly separate the two sources we ask for a spatial resolution of 0.25 arcsec. The largest angular scale is set by the CO photodissociation radius.

Based on previous observations with the Plateau de Bure array with about 1.25 arcsec resolution we find flux peaks of the faintest structures of about 500mJy/beam. Assuming pessimistically that the flux is evenly distributed over the 25 corresponding ALMA beams of 0.25arcsec, we still get a peak flux of 20mJy/beam. The narrowest features seen in our previous observations show a velocity width of about 0.5 km/s. For detecting faint structures, we can thus afford smoothing the spectra over up to five channels. To detect 20mJy/beam at 3 sigma in 0.5 km/s requires a sensitivity of 15mJy/beam in 0.1 km/s. In addition, for the faint structures, away from the center, we can consider binning them spatially.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO2-1HR
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The primary goal is to image the inner circumstellar environment of EP Aqr in the (2-1) rotational line of 12CO and in the adjacent continuum with a spatial resolution of at least 0.1 arcsec, probably through the configuration C36-6. We understand that this will be on a shared risk basis with ALMA.
We are interested in exploring the relations between the bipolar flows, the equatorial region, the central star, and its hypothetical companion.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In the centre of the source, the bipolar flow manifests itself with emission lines of 1 km/s width (double-horn profile). A velocity resolution of 0.1km/s would allow us to well resolve them in their nascent region.

Our primary goal is to map the central part of the cicumstellar shell with the highest spatial resolution possible. As it is a non-standard mode offered on a shared risk basis, we conservatively estimate that a spatial resolution of at least 0.1 arcsec (probably through C36-6) will be obtained at 230 GHz. A resolution of 0.1 arcsec translates to ~8 stellar diameters, which would allow us to start resolving the acceleration region of the wind.

We are interested in the central part of the circumstellar shell in order to explore the region where the wind is accelerated, and shaped as a bipolar outflow. From our modelling (see figure 2 in the proposal), we estimate the flux in the central beam of 1 arcsec to at least 1 Jy for the spectrally broad component (and 3 Jy for the narrow component). It translates to 10 mJy for a synthesized beam of 0.1 arcsec, assuming a uniform brightness distribution. For a signal to noise ratio of 3, assuming a binning over 0.5km/s, we need a sensitivity of 8 mJy. On the continuum, we thus expect to get a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: EP Aqr is one of the nearest mass losing AGB stars, for which previous data show a bipolar outflow observed almost pole on, in addition to evidence of discrete shells in the circumstellar envelope. ALMA will be used to reveal the 3D structure of the circumstellar shell and resolve the close environment of the central star where the wind is accelerated and where the bipolar outflow is initiated. The high quality of the imaging in the CO (1-0) and (2-1) lines will provide a global description connecting the inner and outer regions of the envelope, and will allow us to perform a quantitative comparison with the models that we have already prepared. We propose to use the 12-m Array (with baselines up to 2 km) to observe EP Aqr in band 3 with a 3-point mosaic for a total of 3.2h, and in band 6 with a 14-point mosaic for a total of 2.1h. In addition, ACA will be used to recover short spacings in band 6 (2.8h). Furthermore, we request, on a shared risk basis, a single pointing in band 6 with an extended configuration of the 12-m Array (1.4h). We will thus be able to connect the different regions of the stellar wind of this proto-typical semi-regular variable.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
